issues.title: [Feature Request]: File manager & API

labels.name: 💞 feature
labels.description: Feature request, pull request that fullfill a new feature.

issues.body:
### Is there an existing issue for the same feature request?

- [X] I have checked the existing issues.

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

```Markdown
Hi. Thanks a lot for this project. While I have got RAGFlow working, I was wondering whether you have any documentation on things like

- Connecting with our existing authentication system: How do we do a handshake if a user is already signed up and logged in to our app and we want to avoid 2 signups/logins
- Embedding the assistant as a chatbot. How do we embed the chatbot in our web app?
- Also, we don't want to give users the ability to create assistant or add to knowledgebase but just chat with the knowledgebase. This means, we need to default the knowledgebase we want to use and the assistant we want to use and the admin manages both the knowledgebase and assistants. May I know how do we do this?
```


### Describe the feature you'd like

An easy way to embed my assistant as a chatbot in the website and enable users to chat through the knowledgebase while maintaining history and context individually.

### Describe implementation you've considered

_No response_

### Documentation, adoption, use case

_No response_

### Additional information

_No response_

comments_data.body:
Also, what is the reason for having this? Since we are self-hosting ragflow, why is a 128 document limit required? Is it intended for some reason? Getting this errors when I go above 128 documents in my knowledgebase.

![image](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/assets/1165845/7d060c4b-80ba-4b66-80c2-6d5085323529)

Also, the toast on doing bulk operations come multiple times - once for each item in the UI - eg. enabling multiple files, running multiple files, etc.

![image](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/assets/1165845/f37ba1eb-e472-4171-88c7-edd6b34ed880)

Also, what is the difference between "Enable" and "Run" in the UI? I understand that you do parsing of the docs when I press "Run" but what does "Enable" or "Disable" do?

In addition, is there a way to have the knowledgebase organized by folder structure instead of having it flat to help us in managing it easily?

For eg. we have docs organized like this and we would like to maintain the structure in ragflow as well - as of now, we are doing prefix and storing in flat structure. Having similar structure would help.

![image](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/assets/1165845/f0b798d0-bcfe-4835-ae02-a6029bbdd2a0)

![image](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/assets/1165845/83be7b8d-cf53-40eb-8a82-5b7eaaaa0b13)

To make it simpler for you, you can probably support adding tags during upload and also support filtering of files by tag along with ability to view the list of tags

In addition, when pressing "Next" during bulk upload of files, while it uploads all the files, it stays in the same screen as if the files are not uploaded yet giving no indication.

![image](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/assets/1165845/a9422029-aeb0-4b52-9ea3-6b139bf93c32)

Also, I see an "Upgrade" button in the Team section. Is this meant to be a paid feature of ragflow?

![image](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/assets/1165845/ef1f1215-a2d1-45bd-80cd-468d1d58e1d9)

When the file names are long, there is an overlap in Name and Chunk Number

![image](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/assets/1165845/202e0710-62f2-45f3-9120-d6cc9d8a464f)

When I try to register the second user, it says "No such file or directory" in the response and I am not able to register

![image](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/assets/1165845/0b11c5e2-9d13-4c5b-a814-31c73baf3b5f)

And when I try to login, it says email is not registered.

**UPDATE:** It worked after I setup the PEM file. For some reason the `private.pem` and `public.pem` file were not cloned and I kept getting these errors

![image](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/assets/1165845/4de40d8a-64b9-48ae-80c9-0ee22b2ca061)
If I create a new user, I am not able to see the assistants created by other users. In my case, since I dont want to allow other users to create assistants but just chat with them, how do i do it?

Also, you are assigning tenant_id as user id during queries. So, even if we change the tenant id of a user in the database level, we need to change the code as well everywhere to make sure it works. Rather I assume you should query the tenant of the current user and not the current user id itself.

![image](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/assets/1165845/ceeafaa6-7f13-4175-a89e-ecad332ff9ef)

Another major issue I noticed is that, according to your logic, the assistant is nothing but the dialog. But that will not work if we use the same assistant across multiple users cause the conversation history of other users will also get shared since conversations are mapped to assistants (dialogs).

Rather you should have 3 layers if I am not wrong - Assistants > Dialogs > Conversations and dialogs are mapped to users

> ### Is there an existing issue for the same feature request?
> * [x]  I have checked the existing issues.
> 
> ### Is your feature request related to a problem?
> ```
> Hi. Thanks a lot for this project. While I have got RAGFlow working, I was wondering whether you have any documentation on things like
> 
> - Connecting with our existing authentication system: How do we do a handshake if a user is already signed up and logged in to our app and we want to avoid 2 signups/logins
> - Embedding the assistant as a chatbot. How do we embed the chatbot in our web app?
> - Also, we don't want to give users the ability to create assistant or add to knowledgebase but just chat with the knowledgebase. This means, we need to default the knowledgebase we want to use and the assistant we want to use and the admin manages both the knowledgebase and assistants. May I know how do we do this?
> ```
> 
> ### Describe the feature you'd like
> An easy way to embed my assistant as a chatbot in the website and enable users to chat through the knowledgebase while maintaining history and context individually.
> 
> ### Describe implementation you've considered
> _No response_
> 
> ### Documentation, adoption, use case
> _No response_
> 
> ### Additional information
> _No response_

Thanks for all these issues which are very important.

The above three will be fullfilled in the 'Conversation API' feature we're about to release in the comming week.
The system will produce multiple secrete tokens for a user, then, the other systems can use these tokens integerating with other  own authentication.

> Also, what is the reason for having this? Since we are self-hosting ragflow, why is a 128 document limit required? Is it intended for some reason? Getting this errors when I go above 128 documents in my knowledgebase.
> 
> ![image](https://private-user-images.githubusercontent.com/1165845/322203774-7d060c4b-80ba-4b66-80c2-6d5085323529.png?jwt=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..X4-eB7HnOkeRYGJKk1h4O3bsgq3Pj5wHK6QdXVainZU)

Since the source code is consistent with our demo site code, inorder to save our computation resources, we add this limitation.
We're gona fix this by passing it from evirement variable.

> Also, the toast on doing bulk operations come multiple times - once for each item in the UI - eg. enabling multiple files, running multiple files, etc.
> 
> ![image](https://private-user-images.githubusercontent.com/1165845/322204568-f37ba1eb-e472-4171-88c7-edd6b34ed880.png?jwt=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..aDuNQ_jE6xNPgoJN07RLr27ygwtxLS2NgqCYZjPb_FE)
> 
> Also, what is the difference between "Enable" and "Run" in the UI? I understand that you do parsing of the docs when I press "Run" but what does "Enable" or "Disable" do?

The multiple toasts will be optimized.
Since uploading and parsing is very time-consuming, it's very annoying if user what to test the existence of a specific file.
And it happends a lot in the scenario of optimizing the quality of chat bot.

> In addition, is there a way to have the knowledgebase organized by folder structure instead of having it flat to help us in managing it easily?
> 
> For eg. we have docs organized like this and we would like to maintain the structure in ragflow as well - as of now, we are doing prefix and storing in flat structure. Having similar structure would help.
> 
> ![image](https://private-user-images.githubusercontent.com/1165845/322204297-f0b798d0-bcfe-4835-ae02-a6029bbdd2a0.png?jwt=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..v7HWbjZ6uGANXzjJU9QrO4gumcVpA-BYH7ZLzqY3R5U)
> 
> ![image](https://private-user-images.githubusercontent.com/1165845/322204350-83be7b8d-cf53-40eb-8a82-5b7eaaaa0b13.png?jwt=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..2yTNDdKOl624zFqrddhXyhCigYaVcgZZV2l3rGZoRzc)
> 
> To make it simpler for you, you can probably support adding tags during upload and also support filtering of files by tag along with ability to view the list of tags

It's already in our road map.

> Also, I see an "Upgrade" button in the Team section. Is this meant to be a paid feature of ragflow?
> 
> ![image](https://private-user-images.githubusercontent.com/1165845/322204857-ef1f1215-a2d1-45bd-80cd-468d1d58e1d9.png?jwt=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..poT7fRcSSCxQBf2w3Ckgc9ifBmwE7_JgQdRd2bKXfOU)

Yes， and it's still under developing.

> the PEM file

 The PEM files are for HTTPS. We did't open-souce it.

> Also, you are assigning tenant_id as user id during queries. So, even if we change the tenant id of a user in the database level, we need to change the code as well everywhere to make sure it works. Rather I assume you should query the tenant of the current user and not the current user id itself.
> 
> ![image](https://private-user-images.githubusercontent.com/1165845/322211537-ceeafaa6-7f13-4175-a89e-ecad332ff9ef.png?jwt=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..uN_r7S4zvtqh1AHi2_QwwH51pJvgGr_POSBhos7-D2A)

Good point.

```python
MAX_FILE_NUM_PER_USER = int(os.environ.get('MAX_FILE_NUM_PER_USER', 0))
if MAX_FILE_NUM_PER_USER > 0 and DocumentService.get_doc_count(kb.tenant_id) >= MAX_FILE_NUM_PER_USER:
        raise RuntimeError("Exceed the maximum file number of a free user!")
 ```
Hello, I see that the code has been updated. If that's the case, will there still be a limit on the number of files in the knowledge base?

@jiandandema 
Thanks for all your feedback and suggestions! 🙌

Yes — you can currently adjust the file size limit by modifying the relevant env parameter. 📁⚙️

@tvvignesh 
Thanks for all your feedback and suggestions! 🙌

We’ve gone through the issues you've raised, and we're happy to report that they’ve all been addressed! ✅ Once you've confirmed and closed this feature request, we’ll go ahead and tidy things up on our end too.

Feel free to continue sharing any other thoughts or ideas — constructive feedback like yours is always welcome and helps us improve the product! 💡🚀

Thanks again! 🙏

@which-W Hi. Thanks. While I may not have the bandwidth to test and update you now (working on our own product and occupied with it), I will close this issue, and if at all I find some time to try these again, I will check and report back on updates. Thanks again.

issues.title: [Question]: Knowlegde base crashed?
issues.body:
### Self Checks

- [x] I have searched for existing issues [search for existing issues](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues), including closed ones.
- [x] I confirm that I am using English to submit this report ([Language Policy](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/5910)).
- [x] Non-english title submitions will be closed directly ( 非英文标题的提交将会被直接关闭 ) ([Language Policy](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/5910)).
- [x] Please do not modify this template :) and fill in all the required fields.

### Describe your problem

I just restart docker then the knowledge base crashed like this:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c2837a24-148d-4098-b77a-d6a4fd9a3303)

How can I save the knowledge base?

comments_data.body: And every book appears like above picture, with the exactly same information "{"src_id": "", "tgt_id": "", "description": "", "keywords": [""], "weight": 0.0, "source_id": ["2bebd31400d711f0b03a729d082247bc"]}".
Version is v0.17.2 slim

It seems that searching process still works. But the display is crashed.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f4c339f1-59aa-4c30-ac81-8f84a68a7da1)

But every bottom of chunks are closed, even some of them can't be opened manually

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9c2fbf40-b215-496e-85e0-64fee3e842bd)

And the knowledge graph disapper:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b88e99e2-9727-4ad1-875a-46be9b5edfae)
@KevinHuSh Sorry to bother, but could you please tell me how to fix this? I have spent a lot on this knowledge base. :-(

### RAGFlow image version

v0.16.0-139-g58a8f1f1 full

```Markdown

```

### Actual behavior

Repeated messages

After “Create session with agent”, call “Converse with agent” and get an answer immediately.

issues.title: [Question]: Regarding the performance issues of ragflow parsing multiple PDF or docx files
issues.body:
### Self Checks

- [x] I have searched for existing issues [search for existing issues](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues), including closed ones.
- [x] I confirm that I am using English to submit this report ([Language Policy](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/5910)).
- [x] Non-english title submitions will be closed directly ( 非英文标题的提交将会被直接关闭 ) ([Language Policy](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/5910)).
- [x] Please do not modify this template :) and fill in all the required fields.

### Describe your problem

Hello, my server configuration is 16C128RAM. I deployed RagFlow using Docker Compose, but when I parse four files at the same time, whether PDF or docx, the page freezes. May I ask if it's a server performance issue or if there are some parameters that need to be fine tuned during ragflow deployment. The qwen text-embedding-v3 model I am using. How to solve the performance problem of high concurrency parsing？

comments_data.body:
<!-- Answer -->
Parsing multiple PDF or docx files at once in RagFlow can quickly exhaust CPU and memory, even on a powerful server. This is a known issue, especially when parsing four or more files concurrently, and can lead to deadlocks or the UI freezing. Here are some concrete steps to improve performance and stability:

- Increase the Docker container's memory limit by raising `MEM_LIMIT` in `docker/.env` and restarting the service. This helps prevent memory exhaustion during parsing [[source]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/7602).
- Limit concurrency: Recent versions of RagFlow have added concurrency controls and timeouts to the task executor. If you’re not on the latest version, consider upgrading to benefit from these improvements [[source]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/8466).
- Disable resource-intensive features like reranker, "Auto-keyword", "Auto-question", and "Use RAPTOR to enhance retrieval" in the knowledge base config. These can slow down parsing significantly [[source]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/7535).
- For plain text PDFs, select "Naive" instead of "DeepDoc" as the parser, or use the slim Docker image with DeepDoc skipped to speed up processing [[source]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/7535).
- Each file is parsed by an individual task executor. You can scale out by running multiple `task_executor.py` instances (possibly on different machines) to improve throughput [[source]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/5436).
- If you see tasks getting stuck, monitor the executor's heartbeat in the logs. Sometimes, restarting the `ragflow-server` container is the only way to recover from a deadlock [[source]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/8466).
- For embedding, it's recommended to run the embedding server (e.g., for qwen text-embedding-v3) on a GPU, but GPU acceleration is not required for the RagFlow server itself [[source]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/6442).
- Make sure `vm.max_map_count` is set to at least 262144 for optimal performance [[source]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/7353070f49d4377cce4b106115119e596e1a50b6/README.md).

If you continue to experience freezes, try processing fewer files at a time, and consider scaling out the executor service or distributing the workload across multiple machines. If you need to diagnose bottlenecks, set `LOG_LEVEL=DEBUG` to get more detailed logs during processing [[source]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/7535).

comments_data.body:
Does restricting concurrency mean that I need modify these parameters：
DOC_BULK_SIZE
EMBEDDING_BATCH_SIZE

<!-- Answer -->
No, restricting concurrency in RagFlow does not mean modifying DOC_BULK_SIZE or EMBEDDING_BATCH_SIZE. These parameters only control how many items are processed in a batch within a single task—they affect throughput and memory usage per task, but not how many files or tasks run at the same time. 

To actually limit concurrency (the number of files processed simultaneously), you should adjust the environment variables MAX_CONCURRENT_TASKS, MAX_CONCURRENT_CHUNK_BUILDERS, and MAX_CONCURRENT_MINIO. These directly control how many tasks, chunk builders, and MinIO operations can run in parallel [docs](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/7353070f49d4377cce4b106115119e596e1a50b6/rag/svr/task_executor.py) [faq](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/7353070f49d4377cce4b106115119e596e1a50b6/docs/faq.mdx).

If you want to tune memory usage or batch efficiency, adjust DOC_BULK_SIZE and EMBEDDING_BATCH_SIZE. If you want to restrict how many files are processed at once, set the concurrency environment variables instead.


<!-- Dosu Comment Footer -->

comments_data.body: I upgraded from version 0.16. Should the MAX_CONCURRENT_TASKS, MAX_CONCURRENT_CHUNK_BUILDERS parameters be set in. env or in a docker compose file

<!-- Answer -->
You should set MAX_CONCURRENT_TASKS and MAX_CONCURRENT_CHUNK_BUILDERS in your docker/.env file. Docker Compose loads this file automatically, and RagFlow reads these environment variables at startup to control concurrency. This is the standard approach for recent versions, including after upgrading from 0.16. Setting them directly in docker-compose.yml is possible but less common and usually only needed for special per-service overrides.  
More details: [example](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/5867) | [code reference](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/7353070f49d4377cce4b106115119e596e1a50b6/rag/svr/task_executor.py)

comments_data.body: What are the appropriate values for setting MAX_CONCURRENT_TASKS and MAX_CONCURRENT_CHUNK_BUILDERS parameters on my machine 16C128RAM?

<!-- Answer -->
There are no official formulas for tuning MAX_CONCURRENT_TASKS and MAX_CONCURRENT_CHUNK_BUILDERS based on hardware, but the defaults are 5 and 1, respectively, and are intentionally conservative to avoid resource exhaustion on smaller servers [code reference](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/7353070f49d4377cce4b106115119e596e1a50b6/rag/svr/task_executor.py). With 16 CPU cores and 128 GB RAM, you can likely increase these values, but user reports show that parsing more than 4 files at once can still cause deadlocks or stuck tasks, even on high-resource machines [discussion](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/8466).

A safe approach is to start with MAX_CONCURRENT_TASKS=4 and MAX_CONCURRENT_CHUNK_BUILDERS=2, then gradually increase one at a time while monitoring CPU, RAM, and for any stuck tasks or freezes. If you see resource exhaustion or tasks getting stuck, dial the values back. There are no hard upper limits, so empirical tuning is necessary for your workload and document types. Always restart the containers after changing these values [docs](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/7353070f49d4377cce4b106115119e596e1a50b6/docs/configurations.md).

If you process large or complex PDFs, or use resource-intensive features (like DeepDoc or built-in OCR), keep the concurrency lower. For plain text or lighter workloads, you may be able to push higher.


<!-- Dosu Comment Footer -->

comments_data.body: thinks

You can try building the docker container from the main branch and run from that, they have the latest patch commit [8d9d2cc](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/commit/8d9d2cc0a9009dc59eb5309bdf06e2fd61f86364) which largely fixed this problem.

https://ragflow.io/docs/v0.19.1/build_docker_image

The process is pretty straightforward. The task executor after the fix still likes to faint out once or twice in a while but it's not like 100% guaranteed fail from the very beginning like before. Keep an eye on the container CPU and memory usage could give you a clue if it's working or not. given that you are running on CPU, the RAM usage will obviously be super high; if you see memory usage was less than 1GB, then it means the task executor died and you need to restart `ragflow-server`.
Start more `task_executor.py`.

> Start more `task_executor.py`.

@KevinHuSh Could you elaborate?
@dosubot Say something! What does "Start more `task_executor.py`" means and how do I do it?

<!-- Answer -->
"Start more `task_executor.py`" means running additional worker processes that handle file parsing and background tasks in RagFlow. This increases parallelism, so more files can be processed at once, which helps with throughput and reliability—especially if you’re hitting bottlenecks or freezes with only one executor running.

If you’re using Docker Compose, the recommended way is to add or scale an executor service in your `docker-compose.yml`. There’s a commented-out example in the file you can use as a template. You’d uncomment and adjust it like this:

```yaml
executor:
  image: ${RAGFLOW_IMAGE}
  container_name: ragflow-executor
  env_file: .env
  entrypoint: "/ragflow/entrypoint_task_executor.sh 1 2 3"
  restart: on-failure
  # ...other config (volumes, networks, etc)
```

This example starts three executor processes (with IDs 1, 2, and 3) in one container. You can also scale out by running more containers, each with a different consumer number, or by using Docker Compose’s `scale`/`replicas` feature.

Alternatively, you can run the script manually on any machine that can access your Minio, Redis, MySQL, and Elasticsearch services:  
`python rag/svr/task_executor.py 1`  
Start as many as you want, each with a unique number.

Set concurrency controls (like `MAX_CONCURRENT_TASKS` and `MAX_CONCURRENT_CHUNK_BUILDERS`) in your `docker/.env` file. Monitor CPU and RAM usage as you scale up—more executors mean more parallel work, but also higher resource use. If you see OOM errors or stuck tasks, dial it back a bit.  
[Reference: scaling executors](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/5436) | [docker-compose example](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/42a570a64d9b39b8bf9f6b32d643b611f0f8d76d/docker/docker-compose.yml)

Haha, no hard feelings—I’m here for all the arguments (and the debugging)! 😄

On the technical side: the whole “start more task_executor.py” thing means running extra worker processes to handle more files in parallel, which can help with throughput and reliability. But you’re right: there’s barely any official documentation about scaling executors—most of the info is buried in code comments or the docker-compose.yml file (where the executor service is commented out) rather than in the main docs or .env config [example](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/42a570a64d9b39b8bf9f6b32d643b611f0f8d76d/docker/docker-compose.yml).

If you want to scale, you either run more containers/services with task_executor.py or launch more processes manually, and control concurrency per process with .env variables like MAX_CONCURRENT_TASKS. If you think the docs should be clearer, you’re definitely not alone—lots of folks would appreciate more explicit instructions!

issues.title: [Question]: what knowledge graph database is ragflow using?
issues.body:
### Self Checks

- [x] I have searched for existing issues [search for existing issues](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues), including closed ones.
- [x] I confirm that I am using English to submit this report ([Language Policy](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/5910)).
- [x] Non-english title submitions will be closed directly ( 非英文标题的提交将会被直接关闭 ) ([Language Policy](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/5910)).
- [x] Please do not modify this template :) and fill in all the required fields.

### Describe your problem

What kowledge graph database is ragflow using? Are we able to see which chunk the entity was extracted from?

comments_data.body: @dosu

<!-- Answer -->
RAGFlow doesn't use a traditional graph database like Neo4j. Instead, it stores knowledge graph data in document stores such as Elasticsearch, OpenSearch, or Infinity, depending on your setup. The graph structure itself is managed in memory using NetworkX, and then serialized and stored as chunks in the backend database. 

Entities and relationships extracted from your documents are tagged with a `source_id` that corresponds to the chunk they came from, so you can trace which chunk an entity was extracted from. This info is preserved throughout the extraction and storage process, and you can retrieve it via the chunk's metadata in the database or through the API [[source]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/311e20599fd084d515063cdf4353636f349598a4/graphrag/utils.py) [[source]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/311e20599fd084d515063cdf4353636f349598a4/rag/utils/es_conn.py).

comments_data.body: In our pipeline, we managed to chunk documents beforehand, and then we use the Python API to upload an empty document and then add chunks to the documents. By doing this, I think the knowledge graph is not constructed even thought I've set knowledge graph settings in knowledge base configuration. How can I make ragflow construct knowledge graph in my settings? @dosu

<!-- Answer -->
Knowledge graph construction in RAGFlow is only triggered by the document parsing pipeline—not by uploading chunks directly, even if your knowledge base config enables the knowledge graph. To build the knowledge graph, you need to either upload documents with parsing enabled or explicitly call the parse/async_parse_documents API after uploading your chunks. Manual chunk upload via the Python API does not invoke the entity/relation extraction or graph-building steps, so the knowledge graph won't be created in your current workflow. For your use case, after uploading your document and chunks, make sure to trigger parsing using the appropriate API call (like async_parse_documents) to start knowledge graph extraction and construction. This is by design and consistent across the backend and SDK layers.  
[Reference](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/d6adcc2d5092f21728ba868f8d0c05c8b9ad7c7d/sdk/python/ragflow_sdk/modules/dataset.py)

FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'CTD模块4，5和2_主要内容介绍.txt'
```

Could you help me debug this? What have I missed? @dosu

<!-- Answer -->
The FileNotFoundError happens because RAGFlow’s parsing pipeline expects the actual document file to be present in storage (MinIO) when you trigger `async_parse_documents`. Uploading only an empty document and chunks via the API does not provide the physical file, so the backend can’t find or parse it—hence the error.

To fix this, you need to upload the original document file itself (not just chunks) to the knowledge base, either through the UI or using the Python SDK’s `upload_documents` method. This ensures the file is stored in MinIO under the correct path (`kb_id/filename`) and is accessible for parsing and knowledge graph construction. After uploading the file, you can then trigger parsing (either from the UI or with `async_parse_documents`) and the knowledge graph will be built as expected [[docs: file management]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/d6adcc2d5092f21728ba868f8d0c05c8b9ad7c7d/docs/guides/manage_files.md) [[docs: knowledge base config]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/d6adcc2d5092f21728ba868f8d0c05c8b9ad7c7d/docs/guides/dataset/configure_knowledge_base.md).

If you want to use your own chunking logic, you still need to upload the file first, then let RAGFlow parse it (you can intervene in chunking results after parsing if needed). Manual chunk upload alone won’t trigger the knowledge graph pipeline [[source]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/d6adcc2d5092f21728ba868f8d0c05c8b9ad7c7d/sdk/python/ragflow_sdk/modules/dataset.py).

Let me know if you need details on the upload steps or how to structure your pipeline!

comments_data.body: if I let async_parse_documents do parsing for me, will it override my chunks? @dosu

<!-- Answer -->
No, calling async_parse_documents will not explicitly override your manually uploaded chunks. It processes the original document file and creates new chunks based on the parsing pipeline. Your existing chunks will remain unless the new parsing produces chunks with the same content and document ID hash as your manual ones, in which case they could be overwritten. In general, manual and parser-generated chunks can coexist, and there’s no automatic cleanup or deletion of your manual chunks when parsing runs. Just be aware that chunk updates are asynchronous due to Elasticsearch, so changes might not show up immediately in the UI or API responses [reference](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/d6adcc2d5092f21728ba868f8d0c05c8b9ad7c7d/rag/svr/task_executor.py).

comments_data.body: How to use metadata to filter down chunks when retrieving chunks? @dosu

<!-- Answer -->
Currently, RAGFlow does not support filtering chunks by metadata at retrieval time in the main API or SDK—metadata is attached to results for informational purposes, but cannot be used as a filter condition in queries. This applies to both the REST API and Dify integration; the metadata_condition parameter is ignored and all matching documents are returned regardless of metadata values. Metadata filtering is planned for future releases, but as of v0.19.0, it is not available [reference](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/8301).

If you need property-based filtering, the recommended workaround is to use the "Tag" knowledge base feature: create a tag KB, bulk tag your chunks, and then apply that tag KB to your main KB for downstream filtering [reference](https://github.com/orgs/infiniflow/discussions/8005). For now, direct metadata-based filtering is not possible, but you can prioritize chunks (e.g., by pagerank or tags) and metadata will be shown to the LLM when relevant chunks are retrieved [reference](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/6619).


<!-- Dosu Comment Footer -->
*To reply, just mention [@dosu](https://go.dosu.dev/dosubot).*

comments_data.body:
I found this: You could use Tag functionality. A. create a knowledge base with Tag chunking method. B. Uploading samples of tags. C. Apply the tag knowledge base to the questioned knowledg base.

My question is, when a user (with only certain permissions, already set by the tags) ask a query, how does retrieve process know to only retrieve the chunks set by those tags? @dosu

<!-- Answer -->
RAGFlow does not automatically restrict chunk retrieval based on tags or user permissions set via tags. Permissions are enforced at the knowledge base (KB) or dataset level—if a user has access to a KB, they can retrieve all its chunks, regardless of tags. Tags are mainly used for organizing, ranking, or expanding queries, not for access control. To filter retrieval by tags, you would need to explicitly add tag-based filters (like `{'tag_feas': [...]}`) to your retrieval queries in the API or SDK. Out of the box, RAGFlow does not enforce tag-based access restrictions during retrieval—this would require custom logic in your application layer or pipeline [reference](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/7e87eb2e230aafef9d926364cb41e61f339df4f1/api/db/services/knowledgebase_service.py) [reference](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/5405).

comments_data.body:
A few questions.
1. do I have to upload the document twice, first time to the tag knowledge base A, second time to a real knowledge base B that will be used for retrieval?
2. looks like I have to split the chunks and set tags beforehand, when creating the tag knowledge base. So that means the chunking in knowledge base A should be identical to chunking in knowledge base B, so that the tags can be mapped?
3. Help me locate the function/method used in the code that is responsible for processing filtering based on tags. 
@dosu

<!-- Answer -->
1. You do not need to upload the document twice. The tag knowledge base (with the "Tag" chunking method) acts as a tag set or library. You create it once, upload your tag samples there, and then apply this tag KB to your main knowledge base for tagging and retrieval. The actual document for retrieval only needs to be uploaded to the real knowledge base, not to the tag KB as well [reference](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/5832).

2. Yes, the chunking in the tag KB and the real KB should be consistent. The tag KB is used to auto-tag chunks in your main KB, so the chunk boundaries and content should match for the tags to map correctly. If you split chunks differently, the tags may not align as expected [reference](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/6995).

3. Tag-based filtering is handled generically in the code. The main logic is in the Dealer class (rag/nlp/search.py), specifically the get_filters method, which builds filter conditions—including tags—from request parameters. The search method then applies these filters when querying chunks. There is no dedicated "tag filter" function; any field (including tags like tag_kwd) included in the filter dictionary will be processed and passed down to the data store connector (like ESConnection.search), which translates it into an Elasticsearch filter [reference](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/7e87eb2e230aafef9d926364cb41e61f339df4f1/rag/nlp/search.py).

So, to filter by tags, make sure your retrieval/filter request includes the relevant tag field(s); the backend will handle it as part of the generic filtering mechanism.


<!-- Dosu Comment Footer -->
*To reply, just mention [@dosu](https://go.dosu.dev/dosubot).*

```bash
Progress:

16:48:52 Page(1~100000001): Finish parsing.
16:48:52 Page(1~100000001): Start to tag for every chunk ...
16:48:52 [ERROR][Exception]: BadRequestError(400, 'search_phase_execution_exception', 'Fielddata is disabled on [tag_kwd] in [ragflow_b42a36561ff111f0b485621449caa4ba]. Text fields are not optimised for operations that require per-document field data like aggregations and sorting, so these operations are disabled by default. Please use a keyword field instead. Alternatively, set fielddata=true on [tag_kwd] in order to load field data by uninverting the inverted index. Note that this can use significant memory.')
```
what could've gone wrong? 
@dosu

I see a "Top-N Tags" setting in knowledge base configuration when I specify a tag set. What does it do? 
@dosu

<!-- Answer -->
The "Top-N Tags" setting controls how many of the most relevant tags (from your tag set) get attached to each chunk during the tagging process. When you enable a tag knowledge base, RAGFlow scores all possible tags for each chunk and saves only the top N tags, where N is the value you set here (between 1 and 10) [code reference](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/936a91c5fe72ac32e171faadf726282bc49aada2/api/utils/validation_utils.py) [implementation](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/936a91c5fe72ac32e171faadf726282bc49aada2/rag/svr/task_executor.py). This directly affects downstream retrieval, filtering, and LLM prompting—only these top tags are available for each chunk.

If you want more granular or broader tag coverage per chunk, increase the value; if you want only the most confident tags, decrease it. This setting also applies when auto-tagging user queries for tag-based retrieval [example](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/936a91c5fe72ac32e171faadf726282bc49aada2/rag/app/tag.py).

### Describe your problem
以下这个测试用例没法通过，我用xinference运行了自定义的嵌入式模型， 名称为custom-embedding，但没有通过create_dataset接口调用
`

        rag.create_dataset("test_create_dataset_embed",embedding_model="custom-embedding@Xinference")

comments_data.body:
<!-- Answer -->
RAGFlow v0.19 does allow integration of custom embedding models, but there are important limitations and requirements. The Python API’s `create_dataset` method accepts an `embedding_model` parameter, but the model you specify (e.g., `"custom-embedding@Xinference"`) must be registered and supported by the backend factory. If the model is not properly registered, you will encounter errors or unsupported model messages.

To use a custom embedding model, you need to:

1. Register your model in the `conf/llm_factories.json` configuration file. Add an entry like:
   ```json
   {
     "llm_name": "custom-embedding@Xinference",
     "tags": "TEXT EMBEDDING",
     "max_tokens": 8192,
     "model_type": "embedding",
     "base_url": "http://{domain}/{model_name}/v1"
   }
   ```
   Make sure the `llm_name` and `base_url` match your deployment and API expectations. The model identifier must follow the `<model_name>@<provider>` format, and both parts must be non-empty strings [[source]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/7863).

2. Ensure your model’s API accepts a string (or list of strings) and returns the embedding(s) in a predictable field (typically a list of floats). If your API’s output structure is different, you may need to adapt the embedding handler in RAGFlow’s codebase to parse the response correctly [[source]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/7863).

3. If direct serving of custom models is not supported in your deployment, you can use Ollama or XInference to serve the embedding model as a workaround [[source]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/5871).

If you have already registered your model and still encounter issues, double-check the identifier and ensure the backend recognizes the factory/provider. The backend code asserts that the embedding model’s factory is supported before proceeding [[source]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/ec60b322abfa0174da8125f46dccaf3da2c939bf/api/apps/llm_app.py).

If your use case requires a model that is not natively supported, you may need to write an adapter or subclass the embedding handler to match your API’s response format [[source]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/7863).

Direct serving of arbitrary custom models is not fully supported yet, but the configuration and workaround options above are the current path for custom embedding integration in RAGFlow v0.19.

The progress display of the knowledge graph shows that the knowledge graph supports resuming construction from breakpoint without having to start building from scratch.

comments_data.body: @dosubot

<!-- Answer -->
You can monitor the progress of knowledge graph construction in RAGFlow through the system's internal progress tracking. The codebase uses a progress callback mechanism to update the progress of tasks like knowledge graph construction, and the TaskService manages progress updates and task status. This means you should see progress information in the task logs or UI if exposed by your deployment. The logs provide detailed timestamps and durations for each step—such as parsing, embedding, entity extraction, and merging—which can help you track where time is being spent and monitor overall progress [(example log)](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/6665).

Currently, RAGFlow does not support resuming knowledge graph construction from a breakpoint if the process is interrupted. Attempts to use a 'Resume' parser configuration will result in an error, and the maintainers have confirmed that this feature is not yet implemented [(maintainer confirmation)](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/5922).

To improve construction speed, consider disabling the reranker feature, ensuring proper GPU utilization, and turning off "Use RAPTOR to enhance retrieval" in your knowledge base configuration. For plain text PDFs, using the "Naive" parser instead of "DeepDoc" can also help. Setting debug logging can assist in identifying bottlenecks [(performance tips)](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/7535).

If you need more specific guidance on accessing progress logs or optimizing your setup, let me know your deployment details or where you're running into issues.

comments_data.body: Need to know the progress of knowledge graph construction? How exactly can one check its construction progress. @dosubot

<!-- Answer -->
You can check the progress of knowledge graph construction in RAGFlow by using its internal task tracking system. Progress is managed by the TaskService class, which records updates for each processing step (such as parsing, embedding, entity extraction, and merging). Each task maintains a progress message and a completion percentage, which are updated as the construction advances.

To view progress, you can:

- Use the get_task method (by task ID) or get_tasks method (by document ID) in the TaskService to retrieve detailed progress information, including progress messages and completion percentages. These methods are part of the backend and may be exposed via API or internal admin tools, depending on your deployment. The progress message will show the current step and any relevant status updates, while the progress field (a float between 0 and 1) indicates completion percentage.  
- Check the logs if you have access to the backend. The logs provide timestamps and durations for each step, which can help you monitor where time is being spent and how far along the process is.  
- If you are using the web UI, start file parsing by clicking the play button next to "UNSTART" in the knowledge base file list. Once parsing begins, you may be able to view chunking results and intervene if parsing stalls, though the UI may not show fine-grained progress for knowledge graph construction itself.  

For more technical details, see the documentation on [knowledge graph construction](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/main/docs/guides/dataset/construct_knowledge_graph.md) and the [TaskService implementation](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/main/api/db/services/task_service.py).

If you need to access progress programmatically, refer to the TaskService's get_task and get_tasks methods, which return progress information for each task, or monitor the logs for step-by-step updates. The system does not currently support resuming construction from a breakpoint if interrupted.

comments_data.body: What about the specific instructions? Or which log should I specifically refer to? Could you elaborate on how to operate it
@dosubot

<!-- Answer -->
To check the progress of knowledge graph construction in RAGFlow, you have several options depending on your access and deployment:

**1. Web UI:**  
If you are using the RAGFlow web interface, progress is tracked for each file in the knowledge base. You can view the progress percentage and log messages by navigating to the file list in your knowledge base. Each file entry includes a progress bar and a status message (these are the `progress` and `progress_msg` fields in the backend). When you start parsing (by clicking the play button next to "UNSTART"), the UI will update with the current step and completion percentage. If parsing stalls, you can intervene directly from the UI. The UI may not show every fine-grained step of knowledge graph construction, but it does reflect overall progress and status updates.  
[See interface fields](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/main/web/src/interfaces/database/knowledge.ts)

**2. Backend/API:**  
If you have backend or API access, you can retrieve detailed progress information using the TaskService. The methods `get_task` (by task ID) and `get_tasks` (by document ID) return the current progress, progress message, and status for each task. These endpoints provide the same information as the UI but can be queried programmatically for automation or monitoring.

**3. Logs:**  
For the most detailed step-by-step progress, refer to the backend logs. The knowledge graph construction process logs each major step—such as task reception, parsing, chunk generation, embedding, indexing, entity extraction, merging, entity resolution, and community extraction—with timestamps and durations. These logs show exactly where time is being spent and can help you identify bottlenecks or issues. Example log entries include:
- "Task has been received."
- "Start to parse."
- "Embedding chunks (0.80s)"
- "Entities extraction of chunk 0 1/1 done, 9 nodes, 0 edges, 8206 tokens."
- "Entities and relationships extraction done, 9 nodes, 0 edges, 8206 tokens, 699.70s."
- "Entities merging done, 4.30s."
- "Graph resolution removed 0 nodes."
- "Graph extracted 6 communities in 2.93s."

You can find these logs in your RAGFlow server's standard output or log files, depending on your deployment setup.  
[See example logs](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/6665)

**4. Database (for advanced users):**  
Some log data, such as conversation logs, are stored in the MySQL table `rag_flow.conversation`. However, for knowledge graph construction progress, the most actionable information is in the logs and the progress fields exposed via the UI/API.

**Summary of operation:**  
- For most users, the web UI provides the easiest way to monitor progress.
- For more detail or automation, use the backend API (`get_task`/`get_tasks`).
- For full transparency and troubleshooting, check the backend logs for step-by-step updates.

If you need help with a specific deployment (e.g., Docker, cloud, local), let me know your setup and I can provide more targeted instructions.

comments_data.body: Where can I obtain more detailed logs of knowledge graph construction？ @dosubot

<!-- Answer -->
You can obtain detailed logs of knowledge graph construction in RAGFlow by accessing the backend server logs. If you are running RAGFlow via Docker, logs are stored in a mapped volume (for example, ./ragflow-logs:/ragflow/logs in the Docker Compose configuration). To view the logs in real time, use:

```bash
docker logs -f ragflow-server
```
or, if you want to tail the log files directly:
```bash
tail -f ragflow/docker/ragflow-logs/*.log
```
[Reference](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/blob/main/docs/faq.mdx)

These logs include detailed step-by-step entries for the knowledge graph construction process, such as task reception, parsing, chunk generation, embedding, indexing, entity extraction, merging, and more. Each entry includes timestamps and durations, which help you monitor progress and identify bottlenecks. Example log entries look like:

```
Task has been received.
Start to parse.
Embedding chunks (0.80s)
Entities extraction of chunk 0 1/1 done, 9 nodes, 0 edges, 8206 tokens.
Entities and relationships extraction done, 9 nodes, 0 edges, 8206 tokens, 699.70s.
Entities merging done, 4.30s.
Graph resolution removed 0 nodes.
Graph extracted 6 communities in 2.93s.
```
[Example logs](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/6665)

If you are not using Docker, check your deployment's log directory or standard output for similar entries. These logs provide the most detailed view of the knowledge graph construction process and are essential for troubleshooting and performance monitoring.

### Self Checks

- [x] I have searched for existing issues [search for existing issues](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues), including closed ones.
- [x] I confirm that I am using English to submit this report ([Language Policy](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/5910)).
- [x] Non-english title submitions will be closed directly ( 非英文标题的提交将会被直接关闭 ) ([Language Policy](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/5910)).
- [x] Please do not modify this template :) and fill in all the required fields.

### RAGFlow workspace code commit ID

0.17.2

### RAGFlow image version

知识库中无内容

### Other environment information

```Markdown

```

### Actual behavior

在知识库的“检索测试”中，通过调整相似度阀值和关键词权重，可以筛选出找到的内容，例如：

分别设置为0.3和0.1，就能检索到2条。
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/09a25209-7f3d-4910-9c09-f9e405c8294a)

设置为0.1和0.75，就能找到17条。

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c317c782-b439-4c7b-bd62-3fdcd741abb0)

这两个值越低，检索到的内容就越多，当然跟问题匹配的就越不准。

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8f6993cf-f7c8-4156-883f-6c191a1988a7)

这就证明了这两个值对于知识库检索是有效的，但是在Agent中，这个值就无效了，**无论改到多低，都检索不到。**

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/203088d6-bd36-408c-a7cf-0c8e9cd49de0)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/08393e0c-aa3f-41d2-8d4f-85be0f77c246)

### Expected behavior

_No response_

### Steps to reproduce

```Markdown
连接方式为：
开始>对话>知识库>生成回答>对话
```

### Additional information

_No response_

issues.body:
### What problem does this PR solve?
Add history version save
- Allows users to view and download agent files by version revision history
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c300375d-8b97-4230-9fc4-83d148137132)

_Briefly describe what this PR aims to solve. Include background context that will help reviewers understand the purpose of the PR._

### Type of change

- [ ] Bug Fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New Feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)
- [ ] Documentation Update
- [ ] Refactoring
- [ ] Performance Improvement
- [ ] Other (please describe):

comments_data.body:
Appreciation! Good feature.

All the versions of are saved in local files, which is not a scalable design. Could you refine it by saving them to MySQL?
You could initiate a new table in `db_models.py` here:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3e40d0be-8718-4697-bf37-b5f77c81a53e)

And a service class is needed to get/set data from DB like those:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e9baa7e9-b187-44c8-9fce-eb7c4a966b37)
I don't have much experience with mysql, but I will try
Hi @KevinHuSh,  It's ready
Can I add more feature. Example: model settings agent, agent list by team.

What about #6155 if you're interested in?
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6e058a78-b615-4319-abc4-2abb33c012e9)

In term of back end, it needs a new DB table to store the configuration of a given user.

@isthaison @KevinHuSh 
Apologies, I built a new Docker image using your PR (#6130 ), but there are functional defects in the implementation.
1. build docker image
```shell
$ git clone -b agent-history git@github.com:isthaison/ragflow.git ragflow_6310
$ cd ragflow_6310/
$ git log
commit 6ecbde83ac5fe6c3f1df3ffdd4559c2c54b76d0f (HEAD -> agent-history, origin/agent-history)
Author: so95 <is.thaison@gmail.com>
Date:   Mon Mar 17 17:51:39 2025 +0700

    fixed show create date
...
$ docker build --progress=plain --build-arg LIGHTEN=1 --build-arg NEED_MIRROR=1 -f Dockerfile -t infiniflow/ragflow:ni
ghtly-slim .
```
2. start ragflow service
```shell
$ cd docker
$ sed -i 's#^RAGFLOW_IMAGE=.*#RAGFLOW_IMAGE=infiniflow/ragflow:nightly-slim#' .env
$ docker compose -f docker-compose.yml up -d
```
3. Create an agent using the Customer Service template and save it.
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/11722c10-8c50-4e84-9ee0-88d6b1758625)
4. Download the JSON configuration file, then open a new empty agent to import it, but an error occurred.
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/71d9aacc-bfba-4b52-b3e8-563cecfae16b)

Operation Workflow：
![20250318151249_rec_](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/912b7969-c936-4d9f-a70f-fe8c5c01faaa)
@asiroliu Could you try again. I have adjusted it, so that it can be imported.

@isthaison 
Great! Using the latest commit (a260717), the import issue has been resolved.

@isthaison @KevinHuSh 
**The preview image is misaligned**
1. Create an agent using the Customer Service template and save it.
2. Delete the note component, then save it.
3. The note component is still present in the latest save preview.
4. Delete the other note component, then save it.
5. The first deleted note component has disappeared in the preview, but the second deleted note component is still present.

![20250318153326_rec_](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/64d3c28a-a53b-438b-a86c-5baedb8c16dc)
Hi @asiroliu, the list history don't include the latest version
I had change logic save version. Would you like trying to again

> What about #6155 if you're interested in? ![image](https://private-user-images.githubusercontent.com/12318111/423804506-6e058a78-b615-4319-abc4-2abb33c012e9.png?jwt=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..9dT0qeHbB1kYdaBk3sLwkem_8_1oRUManWUdzeclu2I)

Hello～I have the same issue, port 80 was occupied by nginx server, and i have changed the port of ragflow-server to 81:80. Then I connected to the remote machine via VPN on my local machine【The ragflow-server service was launched on the remote machine】. When I entered "http://localhost:9380/" in the browser on my local machine, it returned {"code":100,"data":null,"message":"<NotFound '404: Not Found'>"}. When I entered "http://ragflow-server container IP:9380/" or "http://localhost:81/" or "http://127.19.0.6:81/" in the browser on my local machine, it showed that the website could not be accessed.【127.19.0.6 is container IP】
**Is there anything i can do to fix this ? **【The remote machine is shared by our group, and I can't make major changes to it.】

<!-- Greeting -->
Hello @KevinHuSh! I'm [Dosu](https://dosu.dev), your friendly bot here to help you solve bugs, answer questions, and guide you as a contributor. I'm ready to assist you while we wait for a human maintainer. How can I help you today?

<!-- Answer -->
To resolve the 404 Not Found error when accessing the RAGFlow application via SSH on a server, try the following steps:

1. **Update the `/etc/hosts` file** to resolve all hosts to `127.0.0.1`:
   ```plaintext
   127.0.0.1       es01 infinity mysql minio redis
   ```

2. **Verify port configurations** in `docker/service_conf.yaml.template` and ensure they match those in `docker/.env`. For example:
   - MySQL port: 5455
   - Elasticsearch port: 1200

3. **Update `proxy.target` in `.umirc.ts`** to point to `http://127.0.0.1:9380`.

4. **Launch services in the correct order**:
   - Start dependent services using Docker Compose.
   - Launch the backend service.
   - Launch the frontend service.

5. **Access the service using the machine's IP address** without specifying port 9380. For remote access, use `http://server-IP:10080`.

Additionally, ensure the following:

- Confirm that the server IP is correct and accessible.
- Verify that RAGFlow is running healthy on the server.
- Check for any network connectivity issues or firewall rules that might be blocking access to port 10080.

If you encounter the `{"data":null,"code":100,"message":"<NotFound '404: Not Found'>"}` error, ensure that your IP address or port number is correct. If you are using the default configurations, enter `http://<IP_OF_YOUR_MACHINE>` (without specifying port 9380 or any port number) in your browser. Also, ensure that the `vm.max_map_count` is set to at least 262144 in `/etc/sysctl.conf` to prevent issues with Elasticsearch containers <sup>[[1]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/7071)</sup><sup>[[2]](https://github.com/infiniflow/ragflow/issues/5746)</sup>.

issues.title: [Bug]: Delimiter setting not working as intended

labels.name: 🐞 bug
labels.description: Something isn't working, pull request that fix bug.

issues.body:
### Is there an existing issue for the same bug?

- [x] I have checked the existing issues.

### RAGFlow workspace code commit ID

na

### RAGFlow image version

v0.15.1-180-g036f37a6 full

### Other environment information

```Markdown
docker windows gpu compose file, no changes
```

### Actual behavior

Using mutli-char delimiter is not working as intended. Setting `word` in backticks does not lead to a chunk on that word. A quick glance at the codebase suggests the way the regex is built may not be handling string delimiters properly (treating them as a collection of individual chars instead)

### Expected behavior

text to delimit on a given string match and be visible as chunks 

### Steps to reproduce

```Markdown
create basic collection
use general parser
update the delimiter section to have `word` as sole value
upload text or md document containing the desired delimiter at intervals
process document in ui and view chunks
note they have not delimited on provided word
```

### Additional information

_No response_

comments_data.body: Just to add to this by inserting a special char e.g. | before every occurance of my desired word and then using that as a single char match, the system delimits as expected
Great find. Thank you for reporting
Could you specify the case?

@KevinHuSh  this happens on any delimiter that is more than one char. Try ingesting a simple text document and chunking on a given word within the doc. It won't work as despite the tooltip ragflow seems to treat a delimiter in backticks e.g. \`mydelim\` as seperate chars not as a whole token/string.

Based on the issues you've provided, after multiple attempts, I found that the system is working fine. Regarding the multi-character segmentation problem you mentioned, I suspect it might be caused by setting the Chunk token number too big, which leads to segmentation issues. I recommend choosing a smaller number like 10 or smaller based on the content.

The chunking workflow is 100% bugged. I would never recommend creating a vector on less than 128 tokens, that's a surefire way to false positives. I did also notice that on longer documents the chunking seems to 'give up' and just lump the latter half of longer TXT files into one giant chunk or two.

I don't know what else to say, the test case is v simple - try chunking a basic text file on a string delimiter supposedly treated as a single token via backticks and watch it fail. I set no other delimiters and the real clue is if I subbed the word with a single char such as a | it worked fine. I kept min tokens at default throughout.

This issue has not been resolved yet. When using the General method to parse PDFs, both multiple separators and a single separator do not work. Reproduction method: Control variables to ensure that the same token is used for each parsing method, regardless of whether there is a delimiter. The parsing block of the document will not change, indicating that even if a delimiter is set, it will not work.

PDFs will not be split just by delimiters.
Uploading TXT files if there're some clear defined delimiters is highly recommanded.
still not fix.
I can confirm...still not fixed

The response to this made me stop using for time being. It's such a big bug, and easy to test using my steps above, I have no confidence in the codebase doing what it claims right now.

Come on devs, take this seriously!!

Two steps:
1. Slice text into segments by delimiters.
2. Merge those segments with the following rules.
A segment with fewer tokens than the chunk size threshold will be combined with the following segments until the token count exceeds the threshold, at which point a chunk is created.

After my testing. Perhaps I have found the temporary solution.
If the file name ends in 'md', it cannot be separated based on the delimiter. It will default to using line breaks for partitioning.
You can correct the division by changing the end of md to txt
I'm experiencing the same issue on my end. Looking forward to a fix.
I think this is because md files are differently parsed than plain files and it's intended?!
As of now, in version 0.18, this bug still exists. Only txt format can work normally, md, docx, and pdf are invalid.
The bug still exists. v0.19.0 slim.
I confirm that the bug is still in v0.19.0

> No.
then. how  to get  an authorized API key to access   it?

> No.

and I saw the codebase  with  @login_required  decorations, how long does this valid session?

>  From copilot

@yangboz The session validity for `@login_required` in Flask is typically managed by the session configuration in your Flask application. By default, Flask sessions are valid until the browser is closed or the session cookie expires. You can configure the session duration using the `PERMANENT_SESSION_LIFETIME` setting in your Flask configuration.

To bypass or authenticate the `@login_required` decorator when using the API directly, you can use API tokens. Here’s how you can do it:

### Step-by-Step Plan

1. **Generate an API Token**: Use the `/new_token` endpoint to generate a new API token.
2. **Use the API Token**: Include the generated token in the `Authorization` header of your API requests.

### Example Code

#### Generate an API Token

```python
import requests

# Replace with your actual URL and user credentials
url = 'http://your-flask-app-url/new_token'
headers = {
    'Content-Type': 'application/json',
    'Authorization': 'Bearer your_user_token'
}
response = requests.post(url, headers=headers, json={})
api_token = response.json().get('data').get('token')
print(f"Generated API Token: {api_token}")
```

#### Use the API Token

```python
import requests

# Replace with your actual URL and the generated API token
url = 'http://your-flask-app-url/some_protected_endpoint'
headers = {
    'Content-Type': 'application/json',
    'Authorization': f'Bearer {api_token}'
}
response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
print(response.json())
```

### Flask Configuration for Session Lifetime

In your Flask configuration file (e.g., `config.py`), set the session lifetime:

```python
from datetime import timedelta

class Config:
    # Other configurations...
    PERMANENT_SESSION_LIFETIME = timedelta(days=7)  # Set session lifetime to 7 days
```

This configuration ensures that the session is valid for 7 days. Adjust the `timedelta` as needed for your application.

```import json
from login import encrypt
from flask_login import login_required, current_user, login_user, logout_user


base_url = 'http://127.0.0.1/v1/user/'

# 登录接口
login_url = base_url + 'login'

# 登出接口
logout_url = base_url + 'logout'

email = "test2@qq.com"
password = "123456"

    'email': email,

}

# 发送登录请求
response = requests.post(login_url, json=login_data)

if response.status_code == 200:
    # 如果登录成功，从响应中获取access token或session信息
    response_data = response.json()
    data = response_data.get('data', {})
    access_token = data.get('access_token')
    headers = {
        'Authorization': f'Bearer {access_token}'
    }

    # 发送登出请求时带上认证头
    logout_response = requests.get(logout_url, headers=headers)

    print(f"Logout response status code: {logout_response.status_code}")
    print(f"Logout response content: {logout_response.json()}")

else:
    print("Login failed:", response.json())
```

There should be a procedure named task_executor.

commit.message:
Adds new Voyage embedding models (#8845)

### What problem does this PR solve?
This PR enhances the application's capabilities by adding support for
four new Voyage embedding models (voyage-3-large, voyage-3.5,
voyage-3.5-lite, and voyage-code-3) to the `llm_factories.json`
configuration file. These models expand the available options for text
embedding tasks, enabling improved processing of text data with a
maximum token limit of 32,000. This addition addresses the need for more
diverse and specialized embedding models to support various use cases
without altering existing functionality.

### Type of change
- [x] New Feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

four new Voyage embedding models (voyage-3-large, voyage-3.5,
voyage-3.5-lite, and voyage-code-3) to the `llm_factories.json`
configuration file. These models expand the available options for text
embedding tasks, enabling improved processing of text data with a
maximum token limit of 32,000. This addition addresses the need for more
diverse and specialized embedding models to support various use cases
without altering existing functionality.

### Type of change
- [x] New Feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)
